conclusion: Determine if the particle has returned to its starting point by analyzing the velocity-time graph and calculating displacement.
The graph shows the velocity of the particle as a function of time.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the velocity is constant at 2 m/s, indicating constant speed in the positive direction.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 2 m/s to 0 m/s, indicating deceleration.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the velocity decreases linearly from 0 m/s to -2 m/s, indicating acceleration in the negative direction.
Displacement is given by the area under the velocity-time graph.
From t = 0 to t = 1 second, the area under the graph is a rectangle with area 2 m.
From t = 1 to t = 2 seconds, the area under the graph is a triangle with area 1 m.
From t = 2 to t = 3 seconds, the area under the graph is a triangle with area 1 m.
The total displacement is the sum of the areas under the graph, considering their signs: 2 - 1 - 1 = 0 m.
Since the total displacement is 0 m, the particle has returned to its starting point at the 3-second mark.
